studyName: Seychelles Coral Bleaching 20 Year Stable Isotope Data

investigators: Levy, O.; Rosenfeld, M.; Yam, R.; Shemesh, A.
studyNotes:
Coral stable isotope (d18O and d13C) data at monthly resolution 
from 6 corals collected near Alphonse Atoll, Seychelles, Indian Ocean. 
Data span the 1998 bleaching event.

publication.title: Heterogeneity of coral skeletons isotopic compositions  during the 1998 bleaching event
publication.citation:
Levy, O., M. Rosenfeld, R. Yam, and A. Shemesh. 2006. 
Heterogeneity of coral skeletons isotopic compositions 
during the 1998 bleaching event. 
Limnology and Oceanography, Vol. 51(2), pp. 1142-1148.
DOI: 10.4319/lo.2006.51.2.1142
publication.abstract:
The vulnerability of coral reefs to climate change, such as 
regional warming, became fully evident during the strong 
1997-1998 El Nino event.  This El Nino episode was associated 
with elevated sea-surface temperatures and caused mass mortality 
throughout many of the world's coral reefs.  We analyzed the 
isotopic manifestation of this event in six Porites sp. coral 
skeletons from different localities in a small atoll (Alphonse) 
at the Seychelles Island. The aim was to validate the use of coral 
stable isotope compositions as recorders of such events in the past. 
The coupling between local-scale environment and global warming 
was weaker then expected, with regional warming being evident 
only when data from five colonies were averaged. Local conditions 
had a large effect on the isotopic compositions of coral skeletons. 
We conclude that future paleoclimate reconstructions, especially 
those attempts to identify past El Nino events, must be based on 
more than a single coral record. Moreover, the strong effect 
of local habitat on the isotopic composition of Porites sp. 
has to be considered when interpreting d13C and d18O records.
